title-group.article-title: The use of multi-criteria decision analysis to tackle waste management problems: a literature review

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratory of Heat Transfer and Environmental Engineering, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece

abstract.p: Problems in waste management have become more and more complex during recent decades. The increasing volumes of waste produced and social environmental consciousness present prominent drivers for environmental managers towards the achievement of a sustainable waste management scheme. However, in practice, there are many factors and influences – often mutually conflicting – criteria for finding solutions in real-life applications. This paper presents a review of the literature on multi-criteria decision aiding in waste management problems for all reported waste streams. Despite limitations, which are clearly stated, most of the work published in this field is reviewed. The present review aims to provide environmental managers and decision-makers with a thorough list of practical applications of the multi-criteria decision analysis techniques that are used to solve real-life waste management problems, as well as the criteria that are mostly employed in such applications according to the nature of the problem under study. Moreover, the paper explores the advantages and disadvantages of using multi-criteria decision analysis techniques in waste management problems in comparison to other available alternatives.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Management of waste has become an issue of critical importance during last decades mostly due to the complexity of waste streams and the steadily increasing produced volumes. Most often, the decision-making process towards efficient waste management requires the consideration of a significant number of usually conflicting criteria in order to come up with the optimal solution among alternative scenarios.

Multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) or multiple-criteria decision analysis is a sub-discipline of operations research that explicitly considers multiple criteria in decision-making environments. MCDM is concerned with theory and methodology that can treat complex problems encountered in business, engineering, and other areas of human activity. A complex problem is characterized by incommensurate and conflicting criteria or objectives such as cost, performance, reliability, safety, productivity and affordability. In the presence of multiple criteria, a unique optimal decision for the problem does not exist but rather many or even infinitely many decisions are suitable (Wieceka et al., 2008). Multi-criteria decision aid (MCDA) is an advanced field of operations research, which provides decision-makers (DMs) and analysts a wide range of methodologies, which are well suited to the complexity of decision problems (Zopounidis and Doumpos, 2002).

Several MCDA methods have been proposed in recent years to help in selecting the best compromise alternatives rather than taking decisions based only on personal thoughts, views or experiences (e.g. Kami and Werczberger, 1995; Opricovic, 2007). Moreover, due to a rapid increase in existing technologies towards confronting waste management problems, decision-makers are forced to select among a wide spectrum of available alternatives. The growing environmental consciousness of society has also raised focus from a local to regional or global scale. In addition, the decision-making process towards efficient waste management requires the consideration of different parameters. To that end, MCDA methods have been proposed in recent years as a means for helping decision-makers in selecting the best compromise among alternatives, as well as providing them a powerful tool towards convincing the public over the optimal waste management strategy. Applications of such multi-criteria methods have gained wide acceptance in the last few years over quantitative models, as the former embody many variables, quantitative as well as qualitative in their analysis (Queiruga et al., 2008). MCDA provides a tool towards meeting the decision-makers’ needs, as well as gaining the widest possible social acceptance.

Waste management requires not only sound technical assessment of risk but also public participation, consultation and stakeholder dialogue on proposed solutions and associated risks. This is more evident for waste streams that need special treatment and certainly a wide public acceptance and consensus among stakeholders, such as radioactive waste management (Kemp et al., 2006). The usefulness of using one MCDA method in combination with life cycle analysis (LCA) modelling as a decision aid tool is considered most critical in the selection of an optimal management strategy in waste management problems (Hanandeh and El-Zein, 2010).

The basic aim of this paper is to provide a systematic literature review on the application of various MCDA techniques to tackle waste management problems. In the framework of the present work, the most widely MCDA methods used are briefly presented and the most common waste streams are discussed (e.g. municipal solid waste, waste water, hospital waste, etc.). In order to organize the review in a more descriptive way, publications are mapped according to the different waste streams they refer to. Since the early 1980s, when Saaty and Gholmnezhad (1982) first published their work on nuclear waste strategies, waste management studies conducted with the use of MCDA methods have gained increasing interest, with the number of relative papers growing from year to year. Additionally, the use of MCDA in waste management has significantly changed over the years. Having commenced with tackling more common waste management problems, for example, municipal solid waste, late trends show use of MCDA in rather special topics, such as disposal of used oil or recycling problems in general. A brief statistical analysis of publications in terms of method used, topic studied, year of publication is also presented. The paper concludes with managerial insights, an attempt to discuss whether one MCDA method seems more advantageous to use in each waste stream, as well as a prognosis of the future of MCDA use in waste management problems.

MCDA methods present significant merits over other alternative decision-making tools, as well as a number of drawbacks. The pros and cons of the MCDA techniques are analytically addressed in the work of Bhagtani (2008). In brief, the key feature of MCDA techniques is its flexibility on the judgement of the decision-making team, which explores the optimal option by assigning performance scores and weights. In addition, MCDA techniques are able to evaluate alternatives against multiple criteria which are measured in different (both quantitative, as well as qualitative) units (Hajkowicz and Higgins, 2006). Furthermore, MCDA techniques are used to identify either the single most preferred alternative, short-list alternatives for subsequent detailed analysis, rank different alternatives or to distinguish acceptable from unacceptable possibilities. Another important feature of MCDA is the performance matrix, where each row represents an option and each column describes performance of the option against each criterion. The performance matrix can be used when moving towards a final decision by comparing alternatives’ performances on a pair-wise basis for all different selected criteria.

On the contrary, there are also some drawbacks of the MCDA methods. One of the major drawbacks is those that are sensitive to uncertainties. For instance, general sources of individual uncertainties could come from data series uncertainties, uncertainty about the future, synergies and idiosyncrasies in the interpretation of ambiguous or incomplete information. In a complex decision-making context, the existence of issues such as interdependence of preferences and double counting presents another type of uncertainty in real-world case studies. Moreover, critical inputs to the mathematical MCDA model (e.g. weighting factors, thresholds) are most often based on the personal views and opinions of the experts involved. To that end, a sensitivity analysis on those critical values is usually performed as a last step of the methodological frameworks. Moreover, computational time for most of the MCDA techniques provides the capability to the decision-maker for simultaneously assessing the consequences of potential variations of parameter values, decision variables and constraints by new model runs. Last but not least, for part of the methodologies addressed within the present literature review, preference and indifference thresholds are determined in order to compare alternatives. By utilizing those thresholds, the techniques do not address only the two ends of the problem, but also intermediate levels in between.

Different stakeholders involved in waste management operations (city authorities, regulators of specific waste streams, environmental managers, researchers etc.) can benefit from such a review in many different ways according to their special needs. Moreover, the use of multi-criteria analysis is not yet widely used despite its advantages. Thus, through this work city authorities and waste managers can be informed on the potentialities of such approaches, their advantages and disadvantages in comparison to other available alternatives, in order to be supported in the selection of the optimal one. From their angle, researchers can benefit by having access to a thorough list of case studies employing MCDA techniques in waste management problems and which methods were used in each case. Most importantly, the reader may have access to the criteria that were employed in the recorded practical applications (according to the nature of the problem under study), which is considered as one of the most critical questions during the decision-making process. Moreover, young researchers can be also inspired in their work by implementing MCDA techniques in future challenges dealing with waste management problems or similar research areas questioned.

sec.title: Brief review of multi-criteria decision aid methods
sec.p: In practice, in most cases strategic, tactical and operational decisions cannot be based on clearly defined quantifiable methods. Instead those rely on accurate quantitative models that fully document the particular selection over other available alternatives. In this context, operational research-based tools have been developed in order to support the decision-making process. MCDA methods are useful tools to help stakeholders make their decision process traceable and reliable. These approaches also help decision-makers undertake a sound reflection of their problem (Aragonés-Beltrán et al., 2010). They present a systematic and mathematically standardized procedure to solve problems –practically establish an optimal compromise – arising from conflicting objectives.

In the material to follow, a brief review of the most widely used MCDA methods is presented. Special focus is given on analytic hierarchy process (AHP), ELECTRE and PROMETHEE which are more commonly MCDA techniques used in waste management problems. Comparisons between ELECTRE III and PROMETHEE I and II are provided in Salminen et al. (1998), between ELECTRE and AHP in Lootsma and Schuijt (1997), and between AHP and PROMETHEE in both Dagdeviren (2008) and Macharis et al. (2004). All three aforementioned methodologies are also compared in Gilliams et al. (2005). Antón et al. (2006) provides various examples of situations in which the aforementioned MCDA techniques can be applied.

Although AHP is one of the oldest MCDA methods, developed in 1980 (Saaty, 1980). AHP is still widely used today. The term ‘analytic’ indicates that the problem is broken down into its constitutive elements. The term ‘hierarchy’ indicates that a hierarchy of the constitutive elements is listed in relation to the main goal while the term ‘process’ indicates that data and judgments are processed to reach the final result. The AHP is based on four axes: (i) reciprocal judgments, (ii) homogeneous elements, (iii) hierarchic or feedback dependent structure, and (iv) rank order expectations.

AHP is conducted in two phases, namely hierarchy tree definition and numerical evaluation of the tree. The hierarchy tree definition starts from the determination of the proposed goal. Then criteria and sub-criteria are defined using the experience of the experts. Finally, the alternatives known a priori represent the leaves of the tree. The evaluation phase is based on pair-wise comparison. The criteria on the same level of the hierarchy are compared to establish relative importance compared to the criterion of the father-level (Bertolini et al., 2006). This process permits one to: (i) obtain values that weight criteria, and (ii) define a ranking of the alternatives while the evaluation is bottom-up. The decision-making process commences by comparing the alternatives with the criteria of the last level. The evaluation continues up to the criteria of the first level, which are then compared to the goal. The mathematical background of the AHP is analytically presented in Saaty (1980).

The main advantages of using the AHP methodology are: (i) the hierarchical structure definition permits to understand all the variables involved and their relationship, (ii) the decisional problem is represented in a structured way, (iii) the method does not replace the personnel involved in the resolution process but integrates all the judgments with structured links, (iv) from simple choice, the decision becomes process (Weck et al., 1997).

Another MCDA method widely used in the field of waste management is ELECTRE III which is the most common method among the ELECTRE family methods (Morrissey and Browne, 2004). In brief, ELECTRE III has the ability to incorporate a large number of evaluation criteria for selecting the optimal alternative, coupled with the possibility of involving a large number of different decision-makers. ELECTRE III requires the determination of three thresholds, namely threshold of negligence, preference and veto in the effort to better adapt to such uncertainties (Roy and Bouysou, 1993). With the use of those thresholds, the technique does not address only the two ends of a problem, but also intermediate levels in between. ELECTRE III can take into account either quantitative (e.g. distances, prices, etc.) or qualitative criteria (e.g. aesthetics, reputation, etc.), since the technique illustrates a very good fit of data in such applications. The mathematical background is analytically presented in Roy (1985) and Roy and Bouyssou (1993).

The PROMETHEE (Preference Ranking Organization Method for Enrichment Evaluations) family of outranking methods, including the PROMETHEE I for partial ranking of the alternatives and the PROMETHEE II for complete ranking of the alternatives, were developed by Brans and presented for the first time in 1982 at a conference organized by Nadeau and Landry at the University Laval, Quebec, Canada (Brans, 1982). PROMETHEE is an outranking method for a finite set of alternative actions to be ranked with the use of criteria, which are often conflicting. The methods of PROMETHEE have successfully been applied in many fields and a number of researchers have used them in various decision-making problems. The PROMETHEE methods have some requisites of an appropriate multi-criteria method and their success is basically due to their mathematical properties and to their particular friendliness of use (Brans and Mareschal, 2005).

On the above basis, a number of modelling options have to be chosen before PROMETHEE can be implemented on any problem. These options include the choice of an appropriate preference function –among six available (Vincke and Brans, 1985) – and the weighting given to each variable. Determination of the weights is an important step in most multi-criteria methods. PROMETHEE II assumes that the decision-maker is able to weigh the criteria appropriately, at least when the number of criteria is not too large (Macharis et al., 2004). The preference function defines how one object is to be ranked relative to another and translates the deviation between the evaluations of two samples on a single parameter into a preference degree. The preference degree represents an increasing function of the deviation; hence, smaller deviations will contribute to weaker degrees of preference and larger ones to stronger degrees of preference (Herngren et al., 2006). The preference function is dependent on the use of two thresholds, namely an indifference threshold representing the largest deviation that is considered negligible and the preference threshold p represents the smallest deviation that is considered as decisive.

The resolution of the multiple-criteria problem with the PROMETHEE method follows a specific stepwise procedure of four discrete steps (e.g. Araz et al., 2007; Wang and Yang 2007). The procedure starts with the determination of deviations based on pair-wise comparisons. It is followed by using a relevant preference function for each criterion, calculating the global preference index, and calculating positive and negative outranking flows for each alternative and partial ranking. The procedure concludes with the calculation of net outranking flow for each alternative and complete ranking. The mathematical background is analytically presented in Brans (1982) and Brans and Vincke (1985).

Apart from the three aforementioned most widely used MCDA methods, there are other methods that are rarely employed in waste management which are briefly presented in alphabetical order. The analytic network process (ANP) was developed by Saaty in 1996, as a generalization of the previously developed AHP methodology (Saaty, 1996). In contrast to AHP, ANP includes a feedback loop for the different criteria and allows interrelations between them. The EP+ method (Vasiloglou, 2000) compares ELECTRE I and PROMETHEE II in order to come up with the best compromise. EP+ is specially developed in order to assist public bodies in waste management problems.

The EUGENE method, named after Rene Eugene Poubelle, was developed in the 1990s as a process-oriented model, based on mixed integer programming (Berger et al., 1998). EUGENE is specially developed for long-term (over 20 years) waste management treatment decisions. The OREST method was developed by Roubens (1982). The methodology defines a preference structure on given sets of actions and criteria. The objective is to find a global preference relation. Because of its independence of chosen scale and interactivity with the parameters, OREST is effective, even with little a priori information. The REGIME method, developed in the 1990s and based on the DEFINIT program, relies on weak commensurability and requires only qualitative information about scores and an ordinal ranking of the criteria. For the decision-making process, a pair-wise comparison is realized. Apart from this differentiation, REGIME is similar to ELECTRE methods (Janssen and Herwijnen, 1994).

The SPORE method was developed in order to assist decision-making in the optimal end-of-life treatment of used oil (Khelifi et al., 2006). SPORE makes use of WISE, a web-based software, which is based on the PROMETHEE’s concept. The THOR method, developed by Simões Gomes (1999), determines the optimal distribution of alternatives according to the criteria previously established by each decision-maker. THOR is also able to quantify uncertainties and eliminate criteria. Its main advantage lies in its ease of understanding and quickness of coming up with an optimal solution. The TOPSIS method was developed in Hwang and Yoon (1981). TOPSIS uses a given decision matrix to determine the optimal and worst alternatives. The ranking of the alternatives is then based on their differentiation from those values.

The multi-objective programming (MOP) method, as one class of MCDA techniques, has been also widely applied to waste management research for tackling MCDA problems in the past years. An integrated scenario-based multi-criteria decision support system was developed for planning water resources management with MOP was developed by Weng et al. (2010).

sec.title: Use of multi-criteria decision aid methods in different waste streams
Municipal solid waste
sec.p: Management of municipal solid waste (MSW) has become most critical over the past decades. Due to the complexity of the stream, a large number of treatment alternatives have been introduced. In this context, efficient MSW management involves critical decisions to be made, such as optimal technologies to employed, location problems, etc. To that end, MCDA methods present valuable tools to decision-makers in their decision- making process. In the framework of the present comprehensive literature review, the majority of the published work deals with this specific waste stream. The first applications of MCDA in MSW problems were published in 1991, with Erkut and Moran (1991), Massam (1991), and Vuk and Kozelj (1991) to use AHP, ELECTRE/TOPSIS and PROMETHEE, respectively in order to identify optimal locations for MSW transfer and disposal facilities.

More specifically, Erkut and Moran (1991) first outlined and analysed the characteristics of the problem of locating public facilities such as landfills utilizing AHP. The methodology was carried out in order to identify the optimal siting of a new sanitary landfill in the city of Edmonton, Canada. According to Massam (1991), until then assessment of potential location sites and impacts were only based on single criterion and the performances of alternatives on that specific parameter. At its first steps, the use of MCDA in MSW problems shows dispersion as regards the method used. As already mentioned, Erkut and Moran (1991) used AHP, Massam (1991) preferred ELECTRE, while Vuk and Kozelj (1991) made use of the PROMETHEE method in order to support the decision-making process.

Since then, the number of publications in the field has steadily increased over the years. The use of MCDA methods in MSW is mainly focused on two primary issues: (i) optimal location for the development MSW treatment facilities, and (ii) optimal MSW management strategy. Location problems often tackle the so called ‘not in my back yard’ (NIMBY) syndrome, also influenced by geographical, political, environmental and economical aspects. Most usually, MCDA methods are used in order to locate new disposal sites, waste transhipment stations, or incineration plants. In order to tackle such problems, the AHP, ELECTRE and PROMETHEE have been used in most cases (Charnpratheep et al., 1997; Contreras et al., 2008; De Feo and De Gisi, 2010; Erkut and Moran, 1991; Garfì et al., 2009; Hokkanen and Salminen, 1997b; Siddiqui et al., 1996; Su et al., 2007; Tavares et al., 2011; Wang et al., 2009).

There are also cases where AHP was used together with a second MCDA methodology. For instance, Aragonés-Beltrán et al. (2010) used ANP (a useful tool for technicians, very close methodological to AHP) in order to select optimal location for the development of a MSW plant. In this work, the selection was considered among six alternative plant sites and 21 criteria. Önüt and Soner (2008) used AHP for the calculation of criteria weights, while using TOPSIS (for fuzzy environment) in order to select the optimal location of a transfer station in Istanbul, Turkey. Similarly, Gemitzi et al. (2007) made use of a combination of MCDA methodology and geographic information systems (GIS) towards identification of the optimal location of a municipal solid waste landfills. More specifically, in this work GIS was used for geographic data acquisition and AHP for the evaluation of alternative sites in Evros Prefecture, Greece. The use of AHP by Garfi et al. (2009) helped decision-makers to compare four different waste collection and management alternatives in refugee camps in Algeria. Furthermore, the equilibrium among different impacts, such as social, environmental and technical, pointed out from the results of the method, assured the appropriateness of the AHP method. The AHP, used for the same reasons in Contreras et al. (2008), in combination with LCA, pointed out that the ranking of the criteria of greenhouse gas emissions and landfill capacity constraints are more critical than the economic criteria.

The ELECTRE method was selected by Norese (2006) where incinerator locations and facilities to store their wastes in Italy were compared and ranked in order to find the optimal location. Following the results of the MCDA, the study continues with environmental impact assessment (EIA) of the suggested alternative, which presents an interesting approach towards integrated identification of the optimal solution. In addition, Karagiannidis et al. (2004) used the ELECTRE methodology in order to compare alternatives for the development of facilities for transferring, sorting, treating and landfilling of wastes at the Region of Peloponnese, Greece, taking also into account current legislation. In the cases of Hokkanen et al. (1995) and Hokkanen and Salminen (1994) the ELECTRE III method provided solutions to the problem of choosing solid waste management systems in the region of Oulu, Finland. Those studies concluded that all the available landfills of the planning region should be exploited and their energy potential should serve the purposes of the region. Cheng et al. (2002, 2003) used the combination of TOPSIS and ELECTRE methods with the aim to evaluate alternative landfill sites according to social, environmental and mainly economic criteria, since their ultimate goal was to minimize total cost.

As far as the PROMETHEE method is concerned, with the use of the ARGOS software Kapepula et al. (2007) examined performances of nine areas around Dakar, Senegal, in nine criteria that were grouped into three groups representing production of wastes, their collection and their treatment. Hokkanen and Salminen (1997a) used the PROMETHEE method and preserve the information obtained by the EIA which has to be performed according to the amount of waste of a waste treatment facility. A combination of PROMETHEE and GAIA methods was selected by Vego et al. (2008) in order to evaluate the advantages of locating waste management centres in the coastal or hinterland zone in the coastal part of Croatia, according to ecological, economic, social and operational criteria. Similarly, Chenayah and Takeda (2005) selected the PROMETHEE method towards evaluation of recycling alternatives and ended up with a solution capable of reducing the generation of MSW in Malaysia. It should be noted that PROMETHEE and ELECTRE are employed in those cases that the decision-maker needs a ranking of the alternatives, instead of identifying an optimal solution.

sec.title: Wastewater
sec.p: Wastewater is adversely affected in quality by anthropogenic influence, encompassing a wide range of potential contaminants. Before those quantities are returned to the environment, closing the loop of the natural hydrological cycle, they need to be properly treated. Wastewater treatment processes have been studied by numerous scientists internationally. Similarly to MSW, MCDA methods have been also applied in the assessment of optimal solutions to practical problems. Margeta et al. (1990) first made use of PROMETHEE in order to rank wastewater disposal alternatives in the case of coastal towns. Since then, six more publications are recorded in the field, with their majority to have been published in the last six years. PROMETHEE and ELECTRE III were primarily selected as the most appropriate methodologies (Al-Rashdan et al., 1999; Aragonés-Beltrán et al., 2009; Bellehumeur et al., 1997; Bottero et al., 2011; Carroll et al., 2004; Khalil et al., 2004; Margeta et al., 1990; Refsgaard, 2006; Vasiloglou et al., 2009).

MCDA was used by Aragonés-Beltrán et al. (2009) and Refsgaard (2006) for the management of water resourses. MCDA was also used in drafting the Water Policy Framework in Jordan (Al-Rashdan et al., 1999). The main environmental considerations in the latter were based on water quality and relation to public health, as well as water use in agriculture and industrial activity. Bellehumeur et al. (1997) and Khalil et al. (2004) applied a combination of PROMETHEE and GAIA in order to evaluate site suitability for sewage effluent renovation. Vasiloglou et al. (2009) used EP+ with the aim of helping researchers and local authorities with optimal wastewater treatment unit location. The selection of an on-site wastewater treatment system for the treatment of domestic effluent with minimal impacts both on the environment and public health was realized in Carroll et al. (2004).

sec.title: Waste electrical and electronic equipment
sec.p: Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE) is a constantly increasing component of the total volume of MSW. Moreover their quantities are expected to continue escalating in the near future (Achillas et al., 2010a). End-of-life EEE products represent important source of valuable raw materials but also a critical waste stream due to their hazardous and toxic substances (Dimitrakakis et al., 2009; Iakovou et al., 2009; Nnorom and Osibanjo, 2009; Zuidwijk and Krikke, 2008). Efficient management assumes the consideration of a number of critical economic, environmental, technical and social criteria while also requiring the joint cooperation of all stakeholders, together with political will and effectiveness (Achillas et al., 2010b).

MCDA approaches were used for the evaluation of site locations for the development of WEEE treatment plants in terms of their combined impact on environmental and economic aspects of alternative scenarios (Achillas et al., 2010c; Queiruga et al., 2008; Walther et al., 2008). Achillas et al. (2010c) made use of ELECTRE III, whereas Queiruga et al. (2008) and Walther et al. (2008) preferred PROMETHEE. Optimal locations of WEEE treatment plants were investigated by Queiruga et al. (2008), where PROMETHEE method was employed. Rousis et al. (2008) made also use of PROMETHEE in order to assess the optimal WEEE management strategy for the case of Cyprus. It should be emphasized that MCDA methods have been employed in WEEE management problems only since 2008, mostly due to the constantly increasing volumes of the specific waste stream and the value they contain, but also due to legislation (EU Directive 2002/96/EC).

sec.title: Construction and demolition waste
sec.p: Waste materials from construction activities constitute nowadays the largest by mass fraction of solid wastes in urban areas. In addition, it is widely accepted that the waste stream contains hazardous materials, such as insulating materials, plastic frames of doors and windows (Fatta et al., 2003). The massive volumes of C&D waste present significant pressure to landfill capacities and have led to considerable environmental concerns (Esin and Cosgun, 2007; Hendricks et al., 2000). The environmental and health impacts of such practices include, apart from the aesthetic degradation, soil and water contamination, air pollution as a result of resulting fires, reduced land and property values, destruction of open spaces and landscape blight (El Haggar, 2007).

Five publications have been recorded dealing with C&D waste management. Three of them focus on optimal C&D waste management strategy (Kourmpanis et al., 2008; Roussat et al., 2009; Simões Gomes et al., 2008). Roussat et al. (2009) selected the ELECTRE III method in order to find the optimal sustainable demolition waste management strategy by taking into consideration economic, social and environmental criteria. For the management of C&D in Cyprus, the PROMETHEE II method was used in Kourmpanis et al. (2008). Geneletti (2010) used spatial multi-criteria analysis in order to identify optimal sitting for an inert landfill. Banias et al. (2010) made use of ELECTRE III in order to come up with an optimal location for the development of a new C&D waste treatment facility.

sec.title: Nuclear/radioactive waste
sec.p: Nuclear/radioactive waste was the first waste stream that drew scientific concern back in the early 1980’s (Saaty and Gholamnezhad, 1982). Merkhofer and Keeney (1987), Briggs et al. (1990) and Delhaye et al. (1991) also made use of MCDA approaches in waste management problems, before similar techniques began to be employed in other waste streams. From a total of seven publications in the field, four have assessed optimal locations for nuclear disposal sites (Bowen, 1995; Merkhofer and Keeney, 1987; Petraš, 1997; Taji et al., 2005), whereas the others (Briggs et al., 1990;Delhaye et al., 1991; Saaty and Gholamnezhad, 1982) deal with optimal strategies in the disposal of that particular waste stream.

sec.title: Other waste streams
sec.p: Hospital wastes have only recently became the centre of scientific concern (Brent et al., 2007; Karagiannidis et al., 2010; Karamouz et al., 2007). Strategic decision-making involves the identification of an optimal managerial system with minimum infection risk in third world countries, selection of optimal disposal system and sterilization of the hospital laundry (Brent et al., 2007; Karamouz et al., 2007; Karagiannidis, 2010). Awareness of industrial waste had become the focus of papers more than a decade ago (Alidi, 1996; Geldermann et al., 2000; Spengler et al., 1998).

AHP was preferred by all research teams for the case of hospital waste and one out of three research teams for the case of industrial waste, whereas the rest of the research teams that assessed industrial waste made use of the PROMETHEE method. In contrast to studies that were concerned with industrial and hospital wastes, hazardous wastes were analysed in respect to the assessment of optimal locations for the development of disposal sites (Cram et al., 2006; Gómez-Delgado and Tarantola, 2006). Only one publication has been recorded dealing with used oils where available regeneration technologies of used oil were ranked and compared according to different criteria (environmental, economic and technical) with the aid of PROMETHEE II method (Khelifi et al., 2006). Last but not least, the work of Leschine et al. (1992) studies any given waste stream and assessing decisions on optimal ocean disposal sites

sec.title: Synopsis of the review
sec.p: For the reader’s convenience, the publications are classified according to waste stream, year of publication and MCDA method. To that end, Table 1 summarizes all published work of MCDA dealing with waste management problems. Moreover, the recorded publications are grouped into two topic categories, namely ‘optimal strategy’ and ‘optimal location’ problems. The former refers to papers investigating the optimal decision-making among different alternative methods (e.g. disposal in landfills, incineration, recycle, reuse, etc.) and/or available technologies (e.g. mass burn, pyrolysis, gasification, plasma incineration, incineration in cement kilns, etc.), while the later refers to papers investigating the optimal locating of a waste management facility (e.g. landfill, waste treatment plant, recycling facility etc.).

sec.p: One of the most critical aspects in any problem involving multiple criteria is the selection of the specific criteria to be employed in the decision-making process. Criteria heavily depend both on the nature of the problem under study (whether optimal location or strategy are questioned), as well as the specific waste stream. In that sense, different criteria are used for the cases of ‘optimal waste management strategy’ and ‘optimal location’. More specifically, Table 2 summarizes the criteria employed in the recorded publications as regards ‘optimal waste management strategy’, whereas Table 3 summarizes the criteria for ‘optimal location’ problems. With regard to waste management strategy problems, it becomes obvious that cost and environmental impacts of alternative strategies dominate authors’ selected criteria. On the contrary, technical (reliability, feasibility, applicability) and social (employment, safety and public health, social acceptance) criteria are not considered in the majority of the studies. Correspondingly, for the optimal location of waste management facilities, the cost and land use parameters are considered in nearly all cases. Furthermore, hydrology, topography and soil of alternative areas, are also taken into account when selecting the criteria, together with site capacity and road access. Policies, institutional settings, financial mechanisms, technology selection and stakeholder participation are coupled with wealth waste management practices, which are also involved in waste management hierarchy that is promoted by European regulations (Pires et al., 2011). Many specific factors determine the most preferred waste management options. Economic, environmental, technical and social criteria are identified on the evaluation of waste management strategy options (Table 2).

sec.p: Figure 1 illustrates the statistical analysis of the publications analysed in this literature review. More specifically, Figure 1(a) illustrates the number of publications over time. It is obvious that the number of publications involving MCDA techniques in waste management problems increased over the past years. This could be partly attributed to the wide acceptance of such methods among scientists and at the same time to the great potentials of computers lately that have strengthened those processes and provided the background for their application. Figure 1(b) depicts the number of publications per MCDA method, while the use of specific MCDA methods over time is presented in Figure1(c). AHP, ELECTRE and PROMETHEE are nearly equally used in waste management problems. However, use of AHP has increased considerably during the last years. Figure 1(d) depicts the use of AHP, ELECTRE and PROMETHEE in terms of the topic (location or strategy) covered.

caption.p: Number of publications classified into; (a) year of publication, (b) MCDA method used, (c) MCDA method used and year of publication, (d) MCDA method used and type of problem studied, (e) waste stream and type of problem studied, (f) waste stream and MCDA method used.

sec.p: It becomes clear that AHP and ELECTRE are used in both location and strategy problems, whereas PROMETHEE is mostly preferred for the identification of optimal waste management alternative strategies. In total, 33 publications are recorded dealing with optimal location, and 37 publications are recorded dealing with optimal strategies. In Figure 1(e) the use of MCDA methods per waste stream is depicted. The majority of scientific work (a total of 37 publications) is published on MSW problems, dealing both with the topics of optimal location (20 publications) and optimal strategy (17 publications). Wastewater and nuclear/radioactive waste follow with eight and seven publications, respectively. Four scientific works have been published for WEEE and C&D waste, respectively, while three, three and two papers have been published on industrial, hospital and hazardous waste streams, respectively. It should be noted that specific waste streams, such as WEEE, C&D waste and hospital waste have only recently been acknowledged and thoroughly studied and therefore published work is rather limited.

Interest in those waste streams is, however, steadily increasing and thus more publications are expected in the near future. Figure 1(f) presents the number of publications per waste stream and MCDA method. Once again, it becomes clear that scientists have made use of several available techniques in their efforts to identify optimal solutions with various waste streams, with the exception of hospital waste in which only AHP was utilized in a total of three publications recorded.

As already discussed, MCDA methods have been implemented in a wide range of different waste streams. However, there are still significant scientific gaps that need to be filled in. There are specific waste streams that despite their significance, have not received adequate scientific attention. These are end-of-life vehicles, paper, glass, batteries, pharmaceuticals, etc. Future research is expected to close such gaps.

sec.title: Managerial insights
sec.p: A critical question that needs to be answered is ‘Why are MCDA methods in waste management so important?’. To answer this question one needs to understand the multi-disciplinary and multi-criteria approach required in order to come up with optimal solutions. To that end, the complexity of particular waste streams needs to be thoroughly assessed. Our world is a limited space, with limited natural resources. Waste management is an area in which great savings can be accomplished, both in terms of required land and minimization of resource and energy use.

On top of the above, the NIMBY syndrome often presents a reason for not implementing projects necessary for social sustainability. In that sense, identification of optimal locations and optimal strategies need to be implemented in order to identify most advantageous solutions. To that end, the environmental consciousness needs to be also addressed when one is talking about effective waste management schemes. The growing trend of ‘green consumerism’, which is characterized by consumer preferences for eco-products and their willingness to pay a premium for goods or services causing fewer burdens on the environment, is also a powerful incentive for producers globally (Achillas et al., 2010d; Afroz et al., 2009; Basili et al., 2006). However, such social criteria, no matter how critical those are for any decision’s effectiveness, need to be co-examined with technological, environmental, and mostly economical concerns. Last but not least, MCDA approaches can offer the background for the identification of optimal solutions.

Additionally, what is also of critical importance in the decision-making process is the selection of the appropriate method to be used in each particular case under study. As already implied, there is no generic rule or formula for the choice of a specific MCDA method for a waste stream. The only criterion considered seems to be the question whether the decision-maker necessitates a ranking of the alternatives, in which case ELECTRE or PROMETHEE are mostly selected, or only to identify the optimal one, when AHP is usually preferred. Undoubtedly, the decision on the MCDA method to be employed is influenced also by the authors’ previous experience and the availability of adequate software.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: With specific aspects of the problem dealt the first waste management models. The concept of sustainable waste management is becoming central in more recent compromising models, which are focused around integrated waste management. These waste management appropriate alternatives for helping decision- makers’ selection could be provided by multi-criteria decision analysis. The registration of applied methods provides the ability for a decision-maker to check consistency and increase reliability of each waste management alternative’s result.

This paper has presented an extensive review of the literature on MCDA in waste management problems. For this purpose, a classification scheme was developed to organize each paper into waste stream assessed, date of publication, MCDA method used and the specific topic addressed. With specific aspects of the problem dealt the first waste management models. The concept of sustainable waste management is becoming critical in more recent compromising models, which are focused around integrated waste management. These waste management appropriate alternatives for helping decision-makers’ selection could be provided by multi-criteria decision analysis. The registration of applied methods provides the ability for a decision-maker to check consistency and increase reliability of each waste management alternative’s result. However, specific limitations are identified and need to be acknowledged.

First of all, the scientific work recorded is exclusively published in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In order to produce a reliable and qualitative list of papers and provide the reader/decision-maker with a roadmap of how MCDA methods can be optimally applied in real life waste management problems, the review has not attempted to shed any light on work conducted and published in conference proceedings, PhD or masters’ theses, diploma dissertations, working papers and textbooks. This was based on the grounds that sources other than peer-reviewed scientific journals can be countless. In that sense, the analysis could not be complete and thus unbiased, unless limited to sources with full access. Moreover, focusing on peer-reviewed scientific journals ensured the quality of papers included in the analysis. Moreover, the search for original papers has been conducted in journals that publish in English and thus other journals that publish in other languages were not considered. Despite limitations, it is the authors’ strong belief that the review herein presented is most comprehensive and involves most of the work published in the corresponding field.

A future research direction, which could be an area of theoretical study, is investigating the marked similarities and differences between MCDA methods. Also, the role for multi-criteria decision support tools in an electronic democracy, allowing the participation of large populations in evaluation of options, should be evaluated. As far as the MCDA classification and sorting methodologies is concerned, future research on this field can be extended towards the validation of the developed models and their uniqueness.
